intro: Acaena macrostemon var. basipilosa, commonly known as the New Zealand spinachberry, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It is characterized by its small, spiny fruits that contain edible seeds. The plant typically grows in coastal and subalpine regions, thriving in well-drained soils. Its leaves are alternate and have a serrated edge, while its stems are often covered in fine hairs. This variety is part of the genus Acaena, which includes several species with similar ecological and botanical features.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena macrostemon var. basipilosa is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the Canterbury and Otago regions. This variety thrives in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas. It is often associated with disturbed soils and can be found along roadsides and in scrublands. The plant is well adapted to the temperate climate of New Zealand and plays a role in local ecosystems.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena macrostemon var. basipilosa was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the early European settlement and has since become naturalized in various regions. The plant thrives in disturbed soils and is commonly found in coastal and subalpine areas. It is considered an invasive species in some parts of its range due to its competitive growth habits. Despite its introduced status, it plays a role in local ecosystems by providing food for native wildlife.
